item.title: Transparent Tor Proxy?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
storms:

Is there a built-in way to enable a Transparent Tor proxy on kicksecure

No.

item.title: Transparent Tor Proxy?
item.dc:creator: @storms
item.description:
Is there a built-in way to enable a Transparent Tor proxy on kicksecure? I’m investigating how appropriate it is for hosting onion sites on a VPS.

What do you think of the solution of enabling corridor on kicksecure?

item.title: ISO milestones?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
A task with “lower difficulty” which does not require any knowledge about derivative-maker (Kicksecure build script):

  • live-build: add dracut support

build-steps.d/3300_create-iso-chroot

./build-steps.d/3300_create-iso-chroot --target iso --flavor kicksecure-xfce

item.title: ISO milestones?
item.dc:creator: @storms
item.description: Are there milestones on github to work towards releasing Kicksecure as an ISO? I know several developers who may be interested in helping to move this along, and would like to know where to point them.

item.title: Consider installing systemd-oomd by default
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Yes. For end-user desktop systems it seems better to keep the bad default behavior of a freeze. Then user has at least some idea what is causing it. By automatically dropping back to the login manager, it looks more like a bug than a low RAM issue.

On servers might make more sense because system administrators wouldn’t need to have to reboot the server. Possibly not all services go offline. And system administrators are more likely to read the logs.

item.title: Consider installing systemd-oomd by default
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
• Import kicksecure ova into vbox
  • Reduce the RAMs to 1026mb
  • Run KS
  • Open terminal and install systemd-oomd
  • Restart KS
  • Open FF, and run:
    ** youtube
    ** facebook
    ** 3mdeb
    ** 3mdeb2020

wait for few seconds and KS gonna log you out, and when you login everything start from fresh.

its like restarting the entire OS without the need to really restart.

not that much of a again (maybe for servers who dont want to restart their servers or so…).

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)

item.description: I just tested it now, and everything is working well.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @DonaldDomain
item.description:
I apologize for any confusion, I understand now. Thank you.

I had read that using a VPN that was paid with identifying information and tor together wasn’t a good idea, and was just wondering if this extended to APT traffic as well.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
DonaldDomain via Kicksecure Forums:

Unless you have a VPN on the router.

No difference.

Okay but if you have a Kicksecure desktop, with a VPN client on the computer, doesn’t all the traffic originating from the desktop travel through the VPN client on the desktop?

Yes.

Therefore the torified Apt travelling through the VPN client on the desktop as well?

Yes.

Or is the apt traffic excluded from that.

No exclusions.

No contradiction to what I said earlier.

This is a certainty.

Because a VPN tunnels all traffic through the VPN. This includes
traffic types such as IP, DNS, web, ssh and… And Tor. For the sake of
VPN connection scheme consideratins, there is nothing special about Tor
traffic versus lets say web traffic.

The VPN connects first before anything else because it runs on the
system level.

Other applications such as IP, DNS, web, ssh and Tor operate only on the
application level.

Just test it by yourself if you don’t believe me. Use Tor Browser or
something. The IP address in Tor Browser will always you’re using a VPN
be a Tor one. This will be independent on whether the host operating
system has a VPN enabled or disabled.

The VPN you’re using on the host operating system or not won’t influence
the IP address you can see in Tor Browser on test websites such as
check.torproject.org.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @DonaldDomain
item.description:
Unless you have a VPN on the router.

Okay but if you have a Kicksecure desktop, with a VPN client on the computer, doesn’t all the traffic originating from the desktop travel through the VPN client on the desktop?

Therefore the torified Apt travelling through the VPN client on the desktop as well?

Or is the apt traffic excluded from that.

Sorry just having trouble understanding.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
DonaldDomain via Kicksecure Forums:

The purpose of torified Apt updates was confusing me if you used a VPN, because the update servers would then get the VPN servers IP address.

No.

Kicksecure apt:
user -> VPN -> Tor -> destination

I don’t know how a user -> Tor -> VPN -> destination would be possible
without installing a VPN inside a Whonix-Workstation that is routed
through a Whonix-Gateway.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @DonaldDomain
item.description:
Ok no problem, the only reason I asked is because I know that this is the case on AOSP, certain default connections avoid VPN tunnel intentionally. Like internet connectivity checks and time.

The purpose of torified Apt updates was confusing me if you used a VPN, because the update servers would then get the VPN servers IP address.

Then arguably degrading the benefits of the feature.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
No attempts to exclude any traffic from any VPNs that the user may or
may not use are being implemented in Kicksecure nor planned. Such weird,
surprising functionality is to be avoided.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @DonaldDomain
item.description: Cool thanks for that resource. I’m just more trying to understand if you use a VPN does the torified Apt traffic also go through the VPN tunnel? Or is it excluded.

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
The Whonix website (not Kicksecure) has a lot on VPN combination theory:

Whonix – 9 May 23

Combining Tunnels with Tor

Information on whether Tor gets more or less secure when combining Tor with tunnels such as VPN, SSH, proxies. (User → Tor → proxy/VPN/SSH → Internet) (User → proxy/VPN/SSH → Tor → Internet)

item.title: APT-Traffic and VPN
item.dc:creator: @DonaldDomain
item.description:
I just wanted to clarify that the torified Apt traffic on Kicksecure is only Apt traffic. In that case, if a user wanted to use a VPN client on there desktop would there be any correlation risks?

Or would it be perfectly okay to use a VPN with the torified apt traffic. I guess my concern is that if I’m using a paid VPN with my identity and torified Apt traffic, I don’t want that to be correlated.

Have I understood this correctly?

item.title: Dracut Debain 12 Kicksecure Distromorph for ram-wipe
item.dc:creator: @DonaldDomain
item.description: Can confirm I followed your instructions, it gets stuck and goes to dracut timeout at boot.

item.title: Dracut Debain 12 Kicksecure Distromorph for ram-wipe
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Option A)
This should’t be required. Just upgrade the system as per usual. Then you have this change anyhow.

Option B)
Manually:

Deleting the file is fine too.

sudo rm /etc/dracut.conf.d/30-grub-live.conf

Then update dracut:

sudo dracut -f

Done.

item.title: Dracut Debain 12 Kicksecure Distromorph for ram-wipe

item.description:

Are you supposed to input

filesystems+=overlay

Currently not required

Or just

Currently not required

I deleted what was in etc/dracut.conf.d/30-grub-live.conf

And posted ## Currently not required

Is this correct and is there a way to fix this without reinstalling the os and starting from scratch?

item.title: Livecheck.sh script broken on bookworm
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: Confirmed.

item.title: Livecheck.sh script broken on bookworm
item.dc:creator: @throwawayforprivacy
item.description:
Please excuse the throwaway account. I just want to anonymously report this issue:
After upgrading Whonix (/Kicksecure) from bullseye to bookworm with the release-upgrade script provided, the livecheck.sh script will allways detect that there is something mounted in read-write (and therefore show this in the systray). This is due to the weird fact, that since bookworm, lsblk -all shows empty loop devices from 0-7 that are all read-write and hence trigger livecheck.sh to believe the system is mounted in read-write.
I was not able to understand why these loop devices are present in bookworm.

This all occurs with the system correctly being mounted in read-only and started with grub-live, therefore confusing users.

item.title: APT sources.list One-Line Format versus DEB822-Style Format
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
ONE-LINE-STYLE FORMAT

deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/derivative.asc] https://deb.kicksecure.com bookworm main contrib non-free

shell command:

echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/derivative.asc] https://deb.kicksecure.com bookworm main contrib non-free" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/derivative.list

DEB822-STYLE FORMAT

Uris: https://deb.kicksecure.com
Types: deb deb-src
Suites: bullseye
Components: main contrib non-free
Signed-By: /usr/share/keyrings/derivative.asc

shell command:

echo "\
Uris: https://deb.kicksecure.com
Types: deb deb-src
Suites: bookworm
Components: main contrib non-free
Signed-By: /usr/share/keyrings/derivative.asc
" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/derivative.list

DEB822 format is

  • supported since Debian bookworm,
  • used by extrepo.

In my opinion, the resulting configuration files /etc/apt/sources.list.d look nicer in DEB822 format. Seems easier to modify.

However, in manual repository adding instructions, one-line style format seems easier for copy and paste.
